data.title: Things to do in the Chattanooga area this week include Taco Week, Top Tomato Festival
data.meta_description: Here's what's happening this week in the Chattanooga area.
data.text:
Here's what's happening this week in the Chattanooga area.

Get your picnics ready

Friday, July 19, has been forecast as Tennessee's most perfect evening of the year for alfresco dining. Cabinet manufacturer Fabuwood used data from WeatherSpark to identify the most perfect evening of summer in each state for an outdoor meal. On that Friday in Tennessee, the temperature is expected to hover around 89 degrees with an 18.5% chance of rain. In Georgia and Alabama, the ideal date will be a week later, July 26. Georgia's evening forecast is 80 degrees with a 21% chance of rain. Alabama's temperature is expected to be 82 degrees with a 22% chance of rain. To determine the dates, Fabuwood analysts decided an ideal nighttime temperature for alfresco dining of around 75 degrees, then combined this with the date with the least chance of rain. This allowed them to map out the data and pinpoint the most perfect evenings of the summer in each state where conditions are closest to the target temperature and the chances of rainfall are most limited.

CALENDAR

ARTS

AREA 61 GALLERY — 721 Broad St., Suite 100. "School's. Out. For. Summer.," by featured artist Mike Holsomback, through July 29. area61gallery.com

AVA GALLERY — 30 Frazier Ave. Association for Visual Arts presents member exhibit, "Things Around the House," and "Covenant College Art Students in New York," through Aug. 2. avarts.org

CHICKAMAUGA BATTLEFIELD VISITOR CENTER — 3370 LaFayette Road, Fort Oglethorpe, Ga. "Mark Thrash — Local Legend, Civil Rights After the Civil War," Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park display of artifacts recovered from archaeological field school in 1975, 30+ years after the death of the former slave who lived within the park and worked for the U.S. War Department from 1894 to 1922. nps.gov/chch

CLEARSTORY ARTS — 1673 S. Holtzclaw Ave. "Elsewhere: Pulling Forth the Invisible," through July 27. clearstoryarts.com

CREATIVE ARTS GUILD — 520 W. Waugh St., Dalton, Ga. Georgia Clay Council works in Gallery Five20, through July 26. "Chasing Yutori," works by Janet Campbell Bradley, in Gallery One11, through July 26. creativeartsguild.org

FRANKLIN COUNTY ARTS GUILD — The Artisan Depot, 204 E. Cumberland St., Cowan, Tenn. "All Things You Can Ride On" community show, through July 28. franklincoarts.org

GALLERY AT BLACKWELL — 71 Eastgate Loop. Photographic Society of Chattanooga summer show, through Aug. 23 (extended). chattanoogaphoto.org

HUNTER MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART — 10 Bluff View. Sunday Studio, drop-in art experiences for families, taking inspiration from the permanent collection or temporary exhibit, "Art Deco Glass," 2-4 p.m. July 14. huntermuseum.org

IN-TOWN GALLERY — 26A Frazier Ave. "Dangerous Drawings," dark and satirical exhibit of acrylic and ink artwork by Doug McCoy, through July 31. intowngallery.com

JEWISH CULTURAL CENTER — 5461 North Terrace. "Mishpachah-Family" exhibit by 44 artists from Israel, the U.S. and Canada, including 12 from Chattanooga. 423-493-0270

LOCALS AT SEWANEE — 49 University Ave., Sewanee, Tenn. Spring show featuring Kellen Mayfield and new works by 10 other artists, through July 27. localsatsewanee.com

MUSEUM CENTER AT FIVE POINTS — 200 E. Inman St., Cleveland, Tenn. "Exquisite Miniatures by Wes and Rachelle Siegrist," through Oct. 1. museumcenter.org

NORTHSIDE GALLERY — Northside Presbyterian Church, 923 Mississippi Ave. Show and sale of works by 12 Chattanooga artists, including first-time exhibitors, through July 22. 423-266-1766

RISING ACTION — Crabtree Farms, 1000 E. 30th St. Debut of Adam Frelin sculptures representing fire and water, 10 a.m.-3 p.m. July 20. Free. Email: brianna@artsbuild.com

RIVER GALLERY — 400 E. Second St. Works by painters Carolyn Ward and June Rollins, through July 31. river-gallery.com

RUBY FALLS — 1720 S. Scenic Highway. "Celebrating 95 Years of Wonder" history exhibit, with rare photos, vintage postcards and newspaper articles, through Oct. 20. Free with attraction tickets: $17-$40 (must buy online). rubyfalls.com

STOVEWORKS GALLERY — 1250 E. 13th St. stoveworks.org

› July 19: Art-A-Nooga Tonight, variety hour with seven minutes for each presenter, 7 p.m.; followed by Chattanooga Noise Night, 8 p.m.

› July 20: Open studios with July's eight resident artists, 3-5 p.m.

TENNESSEE AQUARIUM — 1 Broad St. Two dozen images of National Geographic photographer Joel Sartore's Photo Ark, including species photographed on-site, through December. Included with regular admission: $30-$40. tnaqua.org

COMEDY

BARKING LEGS THEATER — 1307 Dodds Ave. Improv Chattanooga's "Yes, And ..." show, 8 p.m. July 20. $15. barkinglegs.org

THE COMEDY CATCH — 29 Station St. thecomedycatch.com

› July 14: GR Goodwin and Friends, 7 p.m. $20-$25.

› July 17: Open Mic Night, 7 p.m. $7.

› July 18: Cleanish Comedy Showcase, 7 p.m. $15-$20.

› July 19-20: Mia Jackson, 7:30 and 9:45 p.m. $19-$24.

FILM

BOBBY STONE FILM SERIES — Walker Theatre, 399 McCallie Ave. Tickets $11-$13. tivolichattanooga.com

— July 20: "The Princess and the Frog," 3 p.m.; "Romeo + Juliet," 6 p.m.; "The Strangers," 9 p.m.

— July 21: "Big Fish," 2 p.m.

COMMUNITY MOVIE NIGHT — 3653 Tom Weathers Drive, Red Bank. Screening of "Finding Nemo," 7 p.m. July 19. Free popcorn while supplies last. Food trucks for other concessions. Free but register: jgrabe@redbanktn.gov

INTERACTIVE MOVIE NIGHT — Barking Legs Theater, 1307 Dodds Ave. Seed Theatre screening of "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II: The Secret of the Ooze," 7:30 p.m. July 19. $20 with props, $15 without. barkinglegs.org

MUSIC

BARKING LEGS THEATER — 1307 Dodds Ave. Wednesday Jazz with Dexter Bell & Friends, 7:30 p.m. July 17. $10. barkinglegs.org

BARRELHOUSE BALLROOM — 1501 Long St. barrelhouseballroom.com

› July 14: Sunday Funday: Christmas in July brunch show with Danimal, Martelli & Forlines, 1-4 p.m. Free.

› July 17: Randy Steele Bluegrass Night, 6 p.m. Free.

› July 19: Evan Honer, with Leon Majcen, 9 p.m. $20-$25.

› July 20: Neon Moon: '90s Country Tribute with Southern Drawl, 9 p.m. $20-$25.

THE CAVERNS — 555 Charlie Roberts Road, Pelham, Tenn. All times Central. Cave and camping upgrades available. thecaverns.com

› July 14: Hayseed Dixie and Iron Horse, 6 p.m. $49.

› July 19: Sammy Virji, with Ayybo, 7 p.m. $65.

› July 20: Get the Led Out, 8 p.m. $59.

› July 21: Garth and Dolly: A Tribute to Two Country Music Icons, 6 p.m. $49.

CREATIVE DISCOVERY MUSEUM — 321 Chestnut St. Music residency with local blues artist Rick Rushing, 1-3 p.m. Thursdays. Included with admission: $20. cdmfun.org

CUMBERLAND COUNTY PLAYHOUSE — 221 Tennessee Ave., Crossville, Tenn. Crossville native and Grand Ole Opry member Mandy Barnett in concert, 7:30 p.m. CDT July 20. $40. ccplayhouse.com

GOSPEL SINGING — Singing Echoes Park, 150 Bryson Lane, Cleveland, Tenn. Singing Echoes' 55th anniversary sing, featuring 10 guest artists, including the Kingsmen Quartet and Inspirations, July 17-20. $18 in advance, $22 at gate; $60 four-day pass; camping available. singingechoes.com

MCLEMORE SONGWRITERS SERIES — McLemore Club, 32 Clubhouse Lane, Rising Fawn, Ga. Summer series continues with Javier Colon, winner of first season of NBC's "The Voice," 7:30 p.m. July 18. $55. themclemore.com

NIGHTFALL — Miller Plaza, 850 Market St. Summer concert series continues July 19, rain or shine, with opener Jess Goggans at 7 p.m. and headliner Jax Hollow at 8 p.m. Art market starts at 6 p.m.; food trucks begin selling at 6:30 p.m. nightfallchattanooga.com

RIVERFRONT NIGHTS — Ross's Landing, 201 Riverfront Parkway. Free summer concert series continues with headliner Big Bam Boom: America's Hall & Oates Tribute, with opener Paul Childers Band, 6-10 p.m. July 20. riverfrontnights.com

SEWANEE SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL — University of the South's Guerry Auditorium, 68 Georgia Ave., Sewanee, Tenn. Symphonic Sunday, with Cumberland Orchestra and Sewanee Symphony, final event in annual festival, 2:30 p.m. CDT July 14. $25 ticket; $15 livestream. ssmf.sewanee.edu

SONGBIRDS — 206 W. Main St. songbirdsfoundation.org

› July 18: Open Mic Night summer series, hosted by James Snider, 7-9 p.m. (repeats Aug. 8 and 15). Sign-ups start at 6 p.m.; 10 slots available.

› July 20: Chattanooga Girls Rock Showcase, 1 p.m. $10.

SOUNDS OF SUMMER — Market Park Pavilion, Athens, Tenn. Weekly concert series continues with Sugar Lime Blue, 7 p.m. July 19. friendlycityfestivals.com

WALKER THEATRE — 399 McCallie Ave. 1964 The Tribute, 7:30 p.m. July 14. $21-$77. tivolichattanooga.com

OUT & ABOUT

BOOK SIGNING — Author Charlotte Reed, a Chattanooga native, signs copies of her book, "A Journey of Faith," 11 a.m.-2 p.m. July 20 at Carolyn Stewart Public Library, 14 W. Second St., Jasper, Tenn.; and 11 a.m.-2 p.m. July 27 at Beene-Pearson Public Library, 208 Elm Ave., South Pittsburg, Tenn. bookstore.dorrancepublishing.com

CHATTANOOGA MARKET — First Horizon Pavilion, 1801 Reggie White Blvd. Free admission. chattanoogamarket.com

› July 14: Top Tomato, 11 a.m.-4 p.m. $15 for Bloody Mary tasting (six samples, with or without alcohol) to benefit Friends of Finley. Music by Emerald Butler, 12:30 p.m., The Shade Trees at 2 p.m.

› July 21: FiveStar Food Fight, live cooking competition among two farmers, two food truck vendors and a Chattanooga police officer using ingredients sourced from the market and a secret ingredient revealed as the contest starts, 11 a.m.-4 p.m.

CHATTANOOGA PINK BRIDAL SHOW — Chattanooga Convention Center, 1 Carter Plaza. Expo of professionals from all aspects of wedding industry, noon-4 p.m. July 14. Admission fees. thepinkbride.com

CHATTANOOGA RIVER MARKET — Tennessee Aquarium plaza, 1 Broad St. Local artists, crafters and food artisans, 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Saturdays through October. Free admission. chattanoogamarket.com

CHATTANOOGA TACO WEEK — Features $5 taco items at 24 local restaurants, chance to win prizes, July 15-21. chattanoogatacoweek.com

(READ MORE: Restaurant Scene: Get ready for Chattanooga Taco Week)

CHRISTMAS IN JULY — Blue Goose Park, 935 Riverfront Parkway (change from original venue). Includes art, craft and food vendors, fishing for flamingos, bounce houses, 10 a.m.-3 p.m. July 20. Free admission. eventswithkimk.com

(READ MORE: Christmas in July: For some, the most wonderful time of the year comes twice)

CIVIL WAR HISTORY — From Ringgold High School softball field, Sparks Street, Ringgold, Ga. (shuttle to launch site). Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park program with Outdoor Chattanooga and National Park Partners, "Fear and Dread at Ringgold Gap," kayak tour of Ringgold Gap and South Chickamauga Creek, 9 a.m. July 20. Free but register. 423-643-6888

CLAY DAY — Creative Discovery Museum, 321 Chestnut St. Air-dry clay activities and wheel demonstration with Scenic City Clay Arts, noon-4 p.m. July 20. Free with regular admission: $20. cdmfun.org

COTTAGE TOUR & BAZAAR — Monteagle Sunday School Assembly, 18 Sunset Rock, Monteagle, Tenn. Women's Association of MSSA hosts 60th annual event to highlight Chautauqua movement, July 19. Includes tours of five representative, turn-of-the-century cottages and self-guided tours of historic buildings (11 a.m.-3 p.m.); bazaar with fine art, jewelry, home decor, plants and clothing (9 a.m.-3 p.m.); Butterfly Boutique resale shop (9 a.m.-4 p.m.); McCartys of Merigold jewelry lecture (10:45 a.m.); bake sale (9 a.m.-4 p.m.); buffet lunch (11 a.m.-1:30 p.m.) or reserved box lunches (11 a.m.-1 p.m., $18). All times Central. $20-$25. mssa1992.org

(READ MORE: Monteagle, Tennessee: Weekend getaway 45 minutes away)

DATE NIGHT — Frothy Monkey, 1400 Market St. Chef-curated three-course dinner for two, 5-9 p.m. July 18-19 (repeats Nov. 14-15). $70; wine pairing available for $30. Reservations encouraged. frothymonkey.com

GORDON-LEE MANSION TOURS — 217 Cove Road, Chickamauga, Ga. Friends organization opens mansion for self-guided tours 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturdays through Labor Day weekend. $1-$5. Email: friendsglm@comcast.net

HOT AS HELL MARKET — Coolidge Park, 150 River St. Hot and spicy art and farmers market, 10 a.m.-7 p.m. July 20. shopthemarketat.com

JELL-O, JAMS AND JORTS — WanderLinger Brewing Co., 1208 King St. Jell-O shots, Jell-O wrestling, Jell-O tug-of-war, jorts (jeans shorts) contest, live music, 7-11 p.m. July 20. wanderlinger.com

LITERARY INK — Chattanooga Convention Center, 1 Carter Plaza. Literature-themed tattoo convention with cosplay, 11 a.m.-6 p.m. July 14 (last day). $30 daily. literaryink.co

LOOKOUT MOUNTAIN CONSERVANCY — 1835 Old Wauhatchie Pike. Summer volunteer opportunities including removing invasives, managing garden and preparing for fundraiser, 9-11 a.m. Wednesdays. lookoutmountainconservancy.org

MASTER GARDENERS OF HAMILTON COUNTY — Hamilton County Extension Center, 6183 Adamson Circle. "Time To Sow Cool-Season Crops," 10 a.m.-noon July 20. Attend in person or by Zoom. Register for either: mghc.org

MOUNTAINTOP SUMMERS — Rock City Gardens, 1400 Patten Road, Lookout Mountain, Ga. Roam With the Gnomes activities, animal education shows, through Sept. 2. $19-$32 ($5 more at gate). seerockcity.com

PHOTOGRAPHIC SOCIETY OF CHATTANOOGA — St. John United Methodist Church, 3921 Murray Hills Drive. Monthly meeting features David Akoubian on "The Decisive Moment in Wildlife Photography," 7 p.m. July 18; boot camp at 6 p.m. with Lin Prabish discussing "Manual the Easy Way." chattanoogaphoto.org

SKATE STATION — Chattanooga Choo Choo Dome Building, 1400 Market St. Dazey Skate Co.'s pop-up roller rink, with daytime workshops, themed parties at night and private rentals, through Aug. 4. Hours: noon-8 p.m. Wednesday-Thursday, 11 a.m.-10 p.m. Friday-Saturday, 11 a.m.-9 p.m. Sunday. $12 includes skates. dazeyskate.com

STABLE 41 FARMERS MARKET — 214 First St., Fort Oglethorpe, Ga. Farm Fresh Fest, 3-6 p.m. July 18. Bingo Paradise, 9 a.m.-noon July 20. stable41market.com

TAX-FREE WEEKEND - ALABAMA — Sales tax holiday for school-related items, midnight to midnight July 19-21. (Tennessee's follows July 26-28.) Covers clothing up to $100 per item; computers, software and computer supplies up to $750; school supplies up to $50 per item; books up to $30. Complete list of eligible items and exclusions: revenue.alabama.gov

SPORTS

CHATTANOOGA LOOKOUTS — AT&T Field, 201 Power Alley. Chattanooga's Double-A affiliate of Cincinnati Reds vs. Biloxi Shuckers, 2:15 p.m. July 14 (last game in home series). Promotions: donate nonperishable food for free general-admission ticket, Catch on the Field; Kids Run the Bases. $8 and up (discounts for children and seniors). milb.com/chattanooga

CHATTANOOGA RED WOLVES — CHI Memorial Stadium, 1 Stadium Way. Men's professional soccer team vs. Charlotte Independence, 7:30 p.m. July 16. $17 and up. chattanoogaredwolves-sc.com

THEATER

ATHENS COMMUNITY THEATRE — The Arts Center, 320 N. White St., Athens, Tenn. athensartscouncil.org

› July 14: ACT Dessert Series opens with "White Rabbit, Red Rabbit," experimental, one-person show written to be performed by the actor as a cold read, 4:04 p.m. (last show), followed by debrief session at 6:04 p.m. $15-$20. Mature subject matter.

› July 21-23: Auditions for Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman," 6 p.m. (show dates Sept. 20-29).

CHATTANOOGA THEATRE CENTRE — 400 River St. "La Cage aux Folles," last show of 100th season, 7:30 p.m. July 19-20, 2:30 p.m. July 21, 7:30 p.m. July 25-27, 2:30 p.m. July 28, 7:30 p.m. Aug. 1-3, 2:30 p.m. Aug. 4. $25-$35. theatrecentre.com

(READ MORE: Chattanooga Theatre Centre will celebrate Centennial Season with 11 shows)

CUMBERLAND COUNTY PLAYHOUSE — 221 Tennessee Ave., Crossville, Tenn. ccplayhouse.com

› Through Aug. 1: "Steel Magnolias." $19-$35.

› Through Aug. 11: "Anastasia: The Musical." $19-$35.

› July 19-Sept. 8: "Grease." $19-$35.

THE RINGGOLD PLAYHOUSE — Ringgold Depot, 155 Depot St., Ringgold, Ga. "I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change," the company's first musical, 7:30 p.m. July 18-20, 2 p.m. July 21, 7:30 p.m. July 25-26, 2 p.m. July 28. $10-$12. nothinlikeringgold.com

SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL — Humanities Auditorium, Chattanooga State Community College, 4501 Amnicola Highway. Homeschool Shakespeare Troupe performances of "As You Like It," 7 p.m. July 19; "Hamlet," 7 p.m. July 20. Free. Email: mcpclan@epbfi.com

SIGNAL MOUNTAIN PLAYHOUSE — James Boulevard at Rolling Way. Meredith Willson's musical comedy "The Music Man," 8 p.m. July 19-20 (final shows). Lawn chairs may be placed starting at 6 p.m. $5-$15. smph.org

Find more events, and add your own, at timesfreepress.com/cnevents.
